preparation::markdown_card_5::text:
## THINGS TO REMEMBER  
• Make a plan, do not just record everything.  
• Sketch a plan or a script for yourself that you can use during interviews or while recording an interview or report.  
• Contact potential interviewees in advance and give them options for where and when you can meet.  
• Think about what audience you want to reach when deciding what kind of story or format to record.
preparation::markdown_card_0::text:
## In this lesson you will learn:  
• What you should think about before you start your story.  
• How to plan your audio story.  
• How to think about your audience when planning your story.
preparation::markdown_card_3::text:
![Audio Plan](4.png)  
Plan your audio segment before you start recording. Your plan should include:    
• An overview of your segment  
• Who should be interviewed  
• Timeframe for completion  
• Intended length of the program  
• If you are doing an interview, be prepared. For more, see the lesson “Interviewing Techniques” in the Journalism section.

preparation::preview_card_0::header: Finding a good topic is the key part of any audio story, but what is the best way to choose a topic and plan my story?
preparation::quiz_card_2::question: If you wanted to interview the mayor of a major city, how would you proceed?
preparation::markdown_card_1::text:
Before you begin to produce an audio piece, there are a few questions you should answer.  
• What is the most compelling way to tell your story? Is it a story about a specific event, person or issue? Determine whether the story focuses on recent events, the impact of the issue on society, or a story about an interesting person.  
• What is your angle? A good way to think about how to interestingly approach a topic is thinking how it actually affects ordinary people.  
• What audience are you aiming at? What are they interested in?  
• Can you present the story in an engaging, clear, and interesting manner? What different parts does your story consist of?  
• What audio do you want to record? Interviews, signature clips of relevant sounds, sounds that introduce the story?  
• What kind of time frame will you need in order to produce the story?

preparation::quiz_card_1::question: What type of audio segment could you NOT produce if you were alone in the jungle?
preparation::markdown_card_4::text:
Remember to ask yourself: Why are you making this program? Is there a specific audience you want to reach?  
Leave sufficient time for editing and publishing. It is possible you will have to change your plan based on what clips and information you are able to collect.
